text.__SUMMARY__: Ulmus bergmanniana var. lasiophylla C. K. Schneid. is endemic to China, on mountain slopes at elevations of 2100–2900 m in Gansu, Shaanxi, north-west Sichuan, south-east Xizang (formerly Tibet), and north-west Yunnan.
text.Description: The tree is distinguished by Fu (2002) as having "Leaf blade adaxially with densely curved pubescence.  Flowers and fruits February - April".
text.Cultivation: Var. lasiophylla is cold hardy; in artificial freezing tests at the Morton Arboretum  the LT50 (temp. at which 50% of tissues die) was found to be - 27.7 °C. There are no known cultivars of this taxon, nor is it known to be in commerce.
text.Accessions-North America:
Chicago Botanic Garden, US. No accession details; planted in West Collections Area.
Morton Arboretum, US. Acc. no. 45–95. Collected from the wild at an unrecorded site in China.
United States National Arboretum, Washington, D.C., US. Acc. nos. 76218, 68978.
text.Accessions-Europe:
Grange Farm Arboretum [2], Lincolnshire, UK. Acc. no. 1057.
Royal Botanic Garden Edinburgh, UK. Acc. no. 19933397. Wild collected in Kunming, China, by Gothenburg Expedition.
text.External links: "Ulmus bergmanniana var. lasiophylla". Herbarium catalogue. Board of Trustees of the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew. Retrieved 17 October 2016.
